SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRES

No. 2

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

A word of explanation to the person answering this questionnaire:

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual who is asked to answer it has exactly the same experiences as another. Some of the questions here will not apply to your experiences; others may prove impossible for you to answer, so don't worry about leaving blank spaces. Use the extra sheets of paper if there is not sufficient space to answer the questions. Don't hesitate to give details, or describe particular events, if they help to answer the questions.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1914, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

Other Questionnaires

Saskatchewan Archives Questionnaire No. 1, entitled "Pioneer Diet: What Did Western Canadian Pioneers Eat?" is still being circulated. If you have not already answered this, and would be willing to do so, please put a check mark here ( ).

Saskatchewan Archives questionnaires on other subjects will be prepared at a later date. Some of these are listed below. Please mark the ones you would be willing to answer.

- All questionnaires
- Pioneer health conditions
- Pioneer social life; sports and recreation
- Pioneer housing
- Pioneer education and churchwork
- Pioneer farming experience

Preservation of Questionnaires

All questionnaires will be preserved in the Saskatchewan Archives Branch Office at the University of Saskatchewan as part of the permanent record of our province. Please sign your completed questionnaire!

McWilliams, Samuel Henry
260 Johnson St., W., Brookview.
To Sask. - September, 1954.

SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES, REGISTRATION

No. 2

PIONEER EXPERIENCE: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

1. Your full name: Garrett Henry McWilliams
2. Your address: 260 Johnson Street, Brookview
3. Date: April 5, 1954
4. Where were you born? (Give name of place and country): Missouri and Minnesota
5. What was your father's name and occupation?: John McWilliams
6. When did you come to Saskatchewan? (Give month and year): September 1884
7. Mention any other places where you lived before coming to Saskatchewan, giving dates wherever possible:
   - From Missouri to Minnesota
   - From Minnesota to Saskatchewan
8. Are you still living in Saskatchewan? (You do not have to answer this question if you are not living in Saskatchewan)
9. How were your reasons for coming to Saskatchewan? (Through other people? Reading about it? Railroad or government information?)

I came to Saskatchewan because my parents wanted me to go there. They had heard about the land being cheap and the opportunity for a better life. I was very young when we moved, so I don't remember much about the journey. We traveled by train from Missouri to Minnesota, then by boat across Lake of the Woods to Canada. We arrived in Saskatchewan in early spring of 1884.

Once we got here, we had to build our own shelter. We used logs and branches to make a simple hut. It was very difficult at first, but we persevered and eventually built a proper house. We faced many challenges, including harsh winters and limited resources, but we managed to survive and thrive.

In the fall of 1884, we started farming. We planted wheat and corn, and the harvest was good. We also raised cattle and pigs, which provided us with meat and milk. We sold our produce at local markets and saved money to improve our farm.

Over the years, we expanded our land and added more livestock. We also invested in new equipment to make farming easier. Our children helped us on the farm, and they learned valuable skills that would serve them well in the future.

Today, we are proud of what we have accomplished. We have raised a family and built a legacy that will be remembered for generations to come. We are grateful for the opportunity to live in such a beautiful and productive land.
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada? Our Muskoka neighbors thought it was a good idea after making inquiries among them. They came home in a rush. We had a meeting, the friends expressed great interest, but we couldn't say anything back. Some things Johnson said they wouldn't stop doing. The Muskoka ladies helped us along.

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other group)? Our own family

13. What means of transportation did you use? Lake Boats & C.P.R. We started from Toronto by boat. We were on three boats. Very rough trip on Lake Superior. The captain said it was the roughest trip he had ever experienced.

14. What incidents of the journey West do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other excitement, etc.). Crossing Lake Superior very rough. The captain said it was the roughest trip he had made. A lot of people very sea sick. I was one of the worst.

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan? Moose Jaw. Was the North-West Territories then? Yes, divided into provinces & states in 1905.

16. Where did you settle or take up land? Landed formal Regina 1885. $1896 total crop failure 1886. Johnstown & father so young only 2 children. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan. Father discovered pasture fire clay at Bird Hills 1887. Settled on 1/2 Section Spring of 1890. He started his homestead. Didn't take me along for company. Gives 10 acres completed this duties 1892. I stayed on until 1899. 1900 moved to my homestead 18 miles S.S. of City. Lived there till fall of 1935. Retired to city. Still here.

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How after you came? Banking & farming.
11. What was your route? (Think of your journey to done to Eastern Canada)

We started from Toronto by train, then went by boat to Lake Superior. We traveled through Wisconsin and Michigan.

12. What means of transportation did you use?

Car, horse-drawn carriage, train, boat

13. How long did the trip take?

About two weeks

14. What difficulties did you encounter?

Weather conditions, lack of food, sickness

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan?

Winnipeg, Manitoba

16. What was the most challenging aspect of your journey?

Weather conditions and lack of food

17. How many people were in your group?

5

18. When did you arrive in Saskatchewan?

April 1895

19. What was your occupation before coming to Saskatchewan?

Farmer

20. How many children did you have?

3

21. How old were they when you came?

1, 2, 3

22. What do you miss most about living in Saskatchewan?

The community and the people

23. How has life changed since you came?

More modern conveniences, better healthcare

24. What do you think the future holds for Saskatchewan?

More opportunities for growth and development

25. Anything else you would like to say?

Thank you for allowing me to share my experiences. I am grateful for the opportunity to be here today.
19. How often did you write to relatives or friends in your old home?
My parents wrote regularly to relatives in Stafford.

20. If you got married, give the name of your husband or wife along with the date and place of marriage:
Bessie Ann Bartley May 1901

21. Did anyone else come to Saskatchewan because of your recommending it as a place to settle?
Some did + settled in Manitoba.

22. If other members of your family (brothers, sisters, parents, etc.) came west tell when they came and where they settled.
1884 Moose Jaw.

23. Is there any particular experience of pioneer days that stands out in your memory which you would like to record?
July 1886 crop got a nice start & in July it turned sod. Had 4 dry crops killed up head muddy killed ground cracked on 8th and barked pineapple rice plants crack so large young chickens & turkeys also young pigs died but down these cracks I have seen wagons wheels stop down & would have to be lifted out of the ground before with pick or crow bar to release wheel rather than take chance of breaking some part. Wheel rather than ranching in the 80s I had a house whitewashing on hills ranching in the 90s I had a house one day an Sioux Indians asked for corn which I gave them. She then said my Marlin wife helped out ride back there then she said my son was determined at a rock decided he could get my son he was determined at a rock decided he could get.

24. Did you travel about much in the early years? (For business, attending church, some visiting friends, etc.)
How Often? How far? By what means of transport?
To make villages we would go by team or horse & wagon, oxen, stock came away & Indian ladies & squaws came out asking for oats &无缝开口作为。I told them to come in, the shock about sundown if wanted so home. I gathered up some used clothes men just walked until 9 o'clock and Indians walked outside then going to see if the two Bucks liked closeup to the door. I sat & saw until they came in & offered supper, then sharp ended 2 clubs, knifes each on my bed they & feet then wanted to play cards & did not want to get into a game with them, then called very badly demanding you see I had known these Indians for some years. They were younger than they then their wives, Mr. Land been persuaded $50 back to the States, years after leave.

23. Is there any particular experience of pioneer days that sticks out in your memory which you would like to recount?

[Handwritten text not legible]
The Easter Massacre 1876

There were sons of old India.

Well about midnight they decided to leave. I named Joe reached up to grab an overcoat & took down my rifle & intended leaving me behind.

I didn't see it that way so grabbed my gun & we struggled around for a short time. He saw I did not intend he could take my rifle so he picked up his own & walked out. They had all gone back by the States, promised the States, had promised them that if they would they would not punish them & they could draw all their back treaty money. They went back drew their treaty & liked high & decided to come back to Canada & they came back in small lots.
The Baxter Massacre 1876

There were some of old times well about nothing at all they decided to leave named Joe reached up to right over head I heard a shot my rifle flinched I choked Lee out. They say so Engaged my gun & gave them hell around for a short time the same I did not intend he could take my rifle so he rushed into his own & walked out. They held all some back to the States in a forest the States had promised them May they be good by they would Mr. Purnell all their debts nearly done they all went back to Canada they came back in small lots.
II.

2 or 3 families in a group. These were 2 of families. They were very bold. They frightened some ranchers wives where the men were not at home. Joe was known as Big Joe. Later a man Hugh Ferguson a Scot ran a Butcher Shop in Maggiejans. Big Joe done all his slaughtering so after a time Joe was called Joe Ferguson & still goes by that name. He lives on a reserve at Wood Mountain. He says he is over 90 years old. 25. When was the first car used in the community? 1913 or 1914

26. If you owned a car before 1914, when did you buy it? What make? Not before 1916

   in Brinkwater by 500 Line traveled mail then also

   While on Farm once a week we had to deliver butter

34. Did any people move away from your district prior to 1914? What reasons did they have for moving?

1886 Some farmers moved to Manitoba loaded everything they had on wagons and the mills came behind them east. Some had oxen and some had horses.

35. Did many people move away during the 1930s? Did many return?

No one left our district, some left from the South West part of the province.

36. If you or some member of your family have held public office, or have been active in any organizations, mention it here, giving dates wherever possible.

I am the one who was Secretary of the 5th Local of the Provincial Grain Growers Association for 8 years. Also in the Provincial Local of 3rd Class Organized the Old Guard School District No. 5-53. I was the first settler in the district. I had filed on my homestead June 1892. I suggest we call it Old Guard No. 5-53. We had a schoolmaster. He called it the Old Guard Old School Number.

37. If you or any of your family or friends were "first" to have or do something in the district mention it here giving dates wherever possible. (Such as owning the first automobile, combine, organizing the first lodge, etc.)

I was the first councillor when local government district was formed from Brinkwater west. I also bought the first tractor. Our first combine was a Holt in 1926. Some cars before mine bought mine 1916. I was the first chairman of the Old Guard School District No. 5-53 and continued chairman for 18 years.

38. How did the places in your community get their names? (School districts, Post Offices, villages, railway stations, creeks, hills, etc.). Try to give: (1) name and occupation of person suggesting place-name (2) origin and meaning of the name (3) date of its adoption (4) any change in names since the first name was given. Date and reason for change. Give facts or new name as above in (1), (2), (3).

Povaga Named after Indiann Chief Povaga after Charles Brinkwater foreman on bridge over small creek at Brinkwater 1893. Povaga School No. 63 don't know when it was organized. J. Brookfield was teacher in 1885. Named after Miss Catherine School No. 1012 built 1904. Named after district in England by settler from England. Spice School No. 1687 built 1907 by John Clements. First teacher Miss Taylor named after J. H. Spice resident of district. Had a family of 16 children first school meeting was held in his house School built on Sec. 11/15. Bovary School Named after 3 families (R. 25). Named Bovary organized early 90's built on Sec. 1/2 of Sec. 25. J. 15-12-24. West end New School stands on Sec. 27 7/15-24.

41. What do you think are the most important changes in your community since you first came West?

The different methods of farming early days one acre per day planting sod with open & walking plows & done my homes looking that way then horse pulling plow next tractor & power till plots now a fifteen seeder box 18 ft cover 100 acres per day, first binder 6 ft cut now 2 combines one 16 ft cut other 12 ft now 2 combines one 16 ft cut other 12 ft

June 1957
